minor: Yer appendages be grazed and could start bleedin'.
major: Yer wounds be leakin' like a sieve.

islandPresence:
This island seems t' react t' me presence. I often have a weird feelin', like somethin' be watchin' me, but besides th' constant barrage o' bloodthirsty creatures at me heels, that feelin' ne'er leaves me; it follows me even into me dreams. I'm not sure how many more sleepless nights I can lead.

Thar it be again. I felled a tree. I hear it.

Thar it be again. I burned a tree. Th' hummin' continues.

Thar it be again, th' end. I started a forest fire. It's too loud!

{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:{/Th' next pages have undecipherable scribbles and diagrams./}}
pastCivilizations:
We have discovered evidence o' many battles here. Not only that, but civilizations, skeletal remains, abandoned houses, and much evidence t' support some type o' apocalyptic scenario.

Not only that, but it seems t' happen again and again; th' evidence all points t' different ages and different points in time. It appears as though no people be able t' survive and thrive in these lands, like some force be forbiddin' human progress.

These ravenous, unabatin' creatures be not helpin' matters, that's fer sure.
wanderingMerchants:
Throughout me exploration o' th' island, I have run across other people, much t' me surprise. It appears as they were in a similar state as myself; somehow trapped in these lands, strugglin' fer our lives. In th' many cases, these folks were not hostile, and we smartly made friendships.

We traded goods and spoke on our situation. One o' th' folks drove a very hard bargain fer some limestone that I needed. If I was a different type o' person, given our secluded settin', I may have simply just taken it through "other means".

Although it was always me intent t' return t' them fer tradin', try as I might, I could no longer locate them. Either they moved on t' other areas or died. Given th' circumstances o' these harsh lands, I'm guessin' th' latter be true.
trappersJournal:
Usin' techniques and skills me father taught t' me in me youth, I was successfully able t' ward off th' monstrosities usin' traps. Th' snare and th' deadfall become me most useful weapons.

I spent days craftin' traps and placin' them outside me shelter instead o' focusin' on traditional weaponry. Me combat skills be not so great, and I have not found a meaningful resource t' craft armor, so trappin' appeared t' be me best bet t' dispatch these creatures.

I think I just heard me deadfall squish another giant spider. I'll write more on me improvised spider meat meal. Sadly, cookin' be not me forte either.
theForce:
I'm not sure if I can properly explain this. Maybe if I ever see ye in person again, I can walk ye through it. I can show it t' ye if ye have not yet experienced it. I hope that day comes. Sadly, I fear that shall not be th' case.

Thar be a presence here. It's a force. A force that bends things t' its will. It preys on me malevolence. I know I sound mad, but I'm sure o' this.

I have dispatched o' many helpless creatures here. Not me proudest moments t' be sure. That force be th' strongest in those times. Th' times whar I push myself over that perilous moral edge and indulge in me very nature. Th' nature o' us all. T' fight, t' kill, t' dominate.

And yet, th' force wanes as I tend t' me crops and as I slay th' evil things that roam here.

Maybe thar be no force, and this be just a manifestation o' guilt. Me abject want o' a rejection o' progress and t' live a peaceful existence.

I hope I can see ye again. In this life or th' next.

Yer lovin' sister, Margaret.
powderyCatalog:
Th' cornerstone t' some godforsaken recipe worth its weight be a powder o' some kind. A must have tool fer some godforsaken wayward wanderer be a mortar and pestle. Grind away and ye may discover a use fer somethin' ye may have not considered.

Things be so much more than they seem. Turn them into a powder and ye open up so many new possibilities!

{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:{/Th' book describes in detail with markings and illustrations o' each powder type cataloged./}}

1. {_Bone meal from bones._} Fer use with fertilizer and fertile soil t' provide nutrients t' plants.
2. {_Flour from wheat._} Used in bakin' goods.
3. {_Ash from burnt organic material._} Used fer plant fertilizer and mixin' with water t' form ash cement.
4. {_Tannin from tree bark._} Used fer tannin' and leatherworkin' endeavors.
5. {_Refined Sand from beach or desert sand._} Likely useful fer glass and makin' o' green sand fer sand castin'.
6. {_Talcum powder from talc._} T' aid in removin' casted material from sand casts.
7. {_Limestone powder from limestone._} Used as a flux when smeltin' some types o' raw ore.
8. {_Carbon powder from charcoal._} Further refines and increases th' quality o' resultin' metal when smeltin' iron. Can also be used fer makin' water filters.
9. {_Saltpeter from niter._} Refined, powdery niter; used fer preservation and as a chemical reagent in other recipes.

Me fascinations with powders elude me. Perhaps I was a chemist in another life?
travelingBySea: Travelin' by Sea by Edwarde Smith

I have figured it out. I have solved th' demands.

theSlimeRancher:
I'd like t' think I know me fair share about these slimy creatures that plague me gardens and homes on occasion. Be it green or red, slimes or jelly cubes, I now have a handle on them all.

One early mistake that I made was usin' me weak knife t' dispatch them. It appears that slashin' damage causes them t' multiply and split more commonly. Ye be best off with piercin' damage as they be resistant t' blunt damage. Th' more damage ye do, th' less chance they have t' multiply.

Another peculiarity I found when destroyin' these gelatinous gruesomes be that they can only split when thar be room aroun' them. Try killin' them when they be cornered. They will be unable t' proliferate!

Slimes can sometimes act strangely and will merge into other slimes, creatin' a jelly cube. This be especially challengin' if it be a bilge-suckin' jelly cube. Those things can certainly pack a punch and be fairly difficult t' take down. It's good t' keep them separated if ye can.

A sickenin' fact that I discovered awhile ago was that these cannibalistic cruelties will eat other slimes and jellies! Simply offer or place down some slime gelatin and they will become tamed! With this fact, I think I can truly call myself a slime rancher.

{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:{/Th' rest o' th' book contains diagrams and crude sketches describin' various anatomical features o' slimes and jelly cubes./}}
remnantsOfCivilization:
Ye may come across th' remnants o' our very own miniature civilization here on th' island; an ode t' what once was back home. Dependin' on when ye read this, thar may not be much left. Th' gods, or more likely, th' devils, have a habit o' keepin' us humans in check; on this island, even more so. Our progress may be all but lost t' time and th' elements now as I am thrust back into cramped mountain passes and livin' off o' noxious swamp water.

We built walls, we built floors, we built houses; places t' rest our weary heads. We attracted others, almost as if we built a beacon here, callin' out t' other travelers as they wrecked their vessels on our shores gettin' lost in that murky fog that brought us here in th' first place. Were we damnin' them t' a life here? Were we th' perpetrators? Like sirens singin' their cursed songs, lurin' them in. And fer what? A piece o' what we once knew.

Th' history books tell us o' th' falls o' civilizations and th' destruction o' societies lon' in th' past. Human progress be always doomed t' fail. On th' island, that timescale be just much faster it seems.

Signed, yer failed kin', Charles Eaton.
andTheVoidAnswersBack:
There's no rope lon' enough t' reach th' bottom o' these godforsaken briny depths. No stone weighty enough t' make its thunderous crash echo from below.

Yet, thar's somethin' t' these collections o' knickknacks I found as they plunge into th' abyss from me pack. There's no island rubbish heap, so I thought it prudent t' come across a new home fer these scraps and refuse I have accumulated. A ringin' calls back as if I am shoutin' "Good day!" t' this jet-black chasm, and it squeaks back "More!".

It's likely just a trick o' th' mind. More superstitions t' add t' th' growin' list o' oddities that this once skeptical bloke paid no mind to.
thePowerOfTheWrittenWord: Th' Power o' th' Written Word

In early civilizations, scrolls, manuscripts, and other forms o' written text played a vital role in th' development and progression o' society. Fer many ancient cultures, they were a primary source o' knowledge and information, and they were often used as a means o' preservin' and passin' down th' stories, history, and teachings o' th' past.

Th' collection o' bookcases filled with texts all contained in th' same buildin' that we refer t' as a library has had a profound cultural and social impact throughout th' ages. They offer a place fer people t' gather and engage in discussions, exchange ideas, and connect with others who share similar interests.

Overall, th' importance o' th' written word and libraries fer civilization cannot be overstated. They be essential fer preservin' and advancin' human knowledge, fosterin' education, and promotin' cultural and social connections.
theAbnormals:
Durin' our stay here, our party has come across strange creatures. Well, rather, they be familiar creatures, but changed, odd, and stronger. James referred t' them as "abnormals", while Joseph named them "aberrants". We ain't sure which t' go with yet.

We have kept some as livestock. A goat, then a cackle, then a rabbit. They all grew from their original size, but not in th' same way that somethin' grows old. This was different. Th' stranger thin' yet be that they mirrored our party's attributes. It took many months t' discover this, and we still ben't completely convinced o' our findings. But they be as such:

As we trained our sword-fightin', or slayed other beasts here, raisin' our combat tactics, these abnormal creatures became more robust, sturdy, and less likely t' injure; their defensive capabilities doubled.

As we trained our own defense skills through parryin' and blockin' incomin' attacks, it made them seem more aggressive and able t' pack a stronger punch, so t' speak. Albert can attest t' this after gettin' rammed by th' goat on two separate occasions with unworldly vigor.

As we hew stone, fell trees, and as our strength increased, so did their vitality and healthfulness. We witnessed th' rabbit get a deep cut and bleed what seemed like liters o' blood only t' be fine th' next day.

If I had t' make a guess, I think this has t' do with th' strange nature o' this island. It be th' feelin' we all feel. It's almost as if th' trees have eyes here, watchin' our every movement. Th' rocks speak with wide sharp mouths tellin' us t' leave. Th' sea has one thousand arms, pushin' us inland, not allowin' our escape. These creatures be all part o' it.
theSpirits:
As I woke up on th' shores o' this island, th' sun beat down on me, parchin' me lips and dryin' me throat. Confusion and fear gripped me as I soon came t' realize I was stranded here with no boat in sight. Me very first moments here were filled with unease, me hairs standin' on end, especially as th' sun set that night. That feelin' was intensified throughout th' cold and struggle-filled night.

As I survived throughout th' days, I soon learned that this place was not just a forsaken archipelago; it was alive, and not just with strange creatures, but with three enigmatic spirits all connected t' th' island. I discovered these spirits through symbols marked on runes I found as I crafted, built, and survived.

Th' first spirit, that I came t' know as "Da", and depicted as {$DEITY:EVIL}, a symbol whose shape appears t' be a twisted and corrupted horned beast. They were th' restless nights, th' sprained ankle, and th' giant rats always nippin' at me heels.

Th' second spirit, that I came t' know as "Wry", and depicted as {$DEITY:CHAOS}, a symbol representin' multiple branched paths leadin' t' nowhar and possibly everywhere. They were th' ambivalence o' nature itself, th' chaotic dance o' heated combat, or whether this berry was safe t' eat.

Th' third and final spirit, that I came t' know as "Aw", and depicted as {$DEITY:GOOD}, a symbol that recollects feelings o' a soft hug, a safe aura, or a delicate rin' imbued with peace. They were th' good on this island, as little o' it as thar was.

I learned I could control certain aspects o' th' island by invokin' these spirits through th' runes. Through some found texts, I eventually discovered that I could sacrifice these runes at an altar t' transform these runes into more pure and potent forms. Luckily, I was able t' fashion me own altar and luckily th' spirits accepted it as a place o' invocation.

These were not simple spirits after all; these were deities.
nowhereToRun:
Despite our best efforts, our team remains ensnared by th' inexorable grasp o' these enigmatic islands. Each island we discover as we sail outwards be indeed a different island, a different shape, a different climate, but it "feels" th' same. Th' pull o' th' island be still thar. Th' journals we come across speak o' th' same manifestations o' old gods and livin' islands. Is th' island simply transmogrifyin' into these new shapes as we reach some unknown border between them? Is th' island part o' some cosmic die, rerollin' us as we sail th' treacherous seas?

  That bein' said, we have noticed somethin' peculiar. As we chart out th' neighbourin' islands, we notice th' further we push out th' better th' plunder. Th' resources we gather from creatures have increased in quality. Th' booty we dig up be more plentiful.

  Conversely, our proximity t' our island o' origin seems t' draw more kindred spirits t' our cause. Fellow survivors become fast friends, offerin' us invaluable trade and support in our ceaseless struggle t' come across our way back t' our homeland.

challenge.slitherSucker: Deities help me, what be that?!

blunt: A crushin' blow that flattens armor and bones alike.

fire: A heated strike that scorches targets.
cold: A frigid strike that chills enemies.
true: Pure, unmitigated damage that bypasses all defenses.

evil: Th' antithesis o' {$DEITY:GOOD}, {$DEITY:EVIL} be a manifestation o' ferocity, death, and destruction! Simply thinkin' o' it sends shivers down yer spine. Goin' so far as t' invoke it... be challengin' th' denizens o' this territory t' a mortal duel.
chaos: An entity that revels in chaos. It cares not fer ye, nor th' creatures in its domain. Its hand be seen in th' strange beings that roam th' island's heights and its briny depths; it be seen in th' fires that consume th' trees and th' brush; it be seen in just th' simple struggle fer survival. Invokin' it... be t' conjure change.
good: A calmin' breeze. Th' flutterin' o' wings. Life. Knowledge. Creation. Th' force that opposes {$DEITY:EVIL}, seekin' peace, and order, and protection. Invokin' it... be like receivin' a gentle hug.
all: Ancient, unknowable entities that seem t' govern these islands. These entities appear t' have been invoked by past inhabitants o' th' islands in strange, terrifyin' rituals.

evil: A symbol seen aroun' this strange isle, resemblin' th' top o' a staff with curved horns.
chaos: A complex symbol ye noticed carved into a stone cliff, but that ne'er left yer mind.
good: An odd symbol seen often aroun' th' island, resemblin' an eye with a line through it.
all: Glyphs from th' past inhabitants o' these islands. It be not known if their meanings have been preserved.

- When no item be equipped, ye will fight with yer hands.
- When both hands be equipped, ye can parry incomin' attacks.
- Equippin' t' this slot does not cost a turn.
offHand:
- Any held item can be equipped in this slot t' provide defensive bonuses or other equip effects.
- It will not be used t' attack except when two dual wield weapons be equipped.
- When both hands be equipped, ye can parry incomin' attacks.
- Equippin' t' this slot does not cost a turn.

tired: Ye be runnin' out o' energy.

fireStage.embers: Th' fire has reduced t' embers.

win: Ye come across yer way back t' civilization and end yer journey.
Ye sail back and enjoyed a good life with yer swag.
Ye traveled back t' civilization, but be this th' end?
dead: Yer bones lay bleachin', lost t' time.
Th' end be just th' beginnin'.
Sadly, no trace o' ye was ever found.

hardcore: Th' default and definitive way t' play. Death be permanent.
casual: Dyin' will respawn ye in th' last place ye rested or slept, with yer items dropped at th' location o' yer demise. Most creatures be neutral/peaceful unless attacked.
challenge: Randomized difficulty modifiers and a unique set o' quests, intended fer quick play sessions. Savin' be disabled in this mode. Choose th' "Daily" option t' compete with others or yerself fer highscores.
custom: Customize yer game, choosin' from a large set o' difficulty modifiers.

welcome: A short summary o' th' help menu, and links t' more resources on th' game.
Welcome t' th' Early Access version o' Wayward!

Disclaimer: Wayward be currently in beta status and many things will change and improve over time.

This be th' help menu, which ye can use t' learn mechanics o' th' game. If ye can't come across th' information yer lookin' fer in this menu, ye can also visit th' {(https://steamcommunity.com/app/379210/discussions/):Steam Discussion forums}.

If ye want t' keep up with Wayward, please visit th' {(https://www.waywardgame.com):Wayward Website}, {(https://www.reddit.com/r/Wayward):Subreddit}, or {(https://discord.gg/wayward):Discord}.

Want t' help Wayward? Spread th' word, or follow us on one o' th' followin' sites: {(https://www.instagram.com/waywardgame/): Instagram}, {(https://www.facebook.com/waywardgame):Facebook}, {(https://twitter.com/Wayward_Game):Twitter}, or {(https://www.indiedb.com/games/wayward):IndieDB}.
controls: A guide on usin' th' bindings associated with common actions in th' game, t' speed up gameplay, and other related tips and tricks.
Learn common bindings fer th' game.
interface: How t' interact with and customize th' windows/dialogs.

Wayward uses dialogs, or windows, fer displayin' most in-game information. This means th' interface be almost completely customizable.

Ye can move th' dialogs by draggin' them by th' title bar, and ye can resize them by draggin' on their edges or corners.

Th' "static" elements on th' screen, namely, yer stats, th' menu bar, and th' list o' messages, can all be moved t' other corners or edges o' th' screen, usin' th' options in their context menus usin' {BINDINGS:MenuContextMenu}. Th' list o' messages can be put into a dialog with {BINDINGS:DialogMessages} or usin' th' "Show Messages As Dialog" settin' in its context menu.

Th' interface setup fer each world be retained between savin' and loadin' th' game.
inventoryManagement: Learn ways o' usin', organizin', movin', and droppin' items.

Thar be many ways t' organize and move items in Wayward.

1. {_Drag and Drop_}: By holdin' {BINDINGS:GameItemMove}, ye may drag and drop items into a container dialog, action slot, equipment slot, or directly on t' th' ground. Draggin' and droppin' t' th' game screen will drop it in front o' ye, or inside a chest if ye be facin' one.

2. {_Quickmovin'_}: With {BINDINGS:GameItemQuickMove} ye can move an item instantly from yer duffle t' a container or vice-versa. Ye can use this while th' container be not open, if yer character be facin' towards it. Ye may also use {BINDINGS:GameItemQuickMoveAll} t' instantly move all items o' th' same type.

3. {_From th' item's menu_}: Ye can use {(HELP/ACTIONS):actions} t' drop and move items as well: namely, "Drop", "Drop All", "Move", and "Move All". Th' "Move" actions will only appear if thar be a container dialog open. Additionally, thar be an option t' drop and move all items o' th' same {(HELP/ITEM_QUALITIES):quality}.

4. {_Droppin' items_}: By pressin' {BINDINGS:GameItemDrop}, ye may drop an item onto th' ground. If th' tile in front o' ye be blocked, nothin' will happen, or th' item will be dropped at yer feet, if yer {(DIALOG/3):"Drop Location" gameplay setting} be set t' "Drop at Feet When Blocked". Ye may also press {BINDINGS:GameItemDropAll} t' drop all items o' th' same type.

5. {_Equippin' items_}: With {BINDINGS:GameItemEquipToggle} ye can easily equip or unequip items directly from yer duffle without needin' t' open th' equipment dialog.

5. {_Protectin' items_}: Usin' {BINDINGS:GameItemProtectToggle} ye can {(HELP/ITEM_PROTECTION):protect} and unprotect items without needin' t' toggle protection from th' item's menu.
actionSlots: Learn th' easier way t' use actions on items.
Th' easier way t' use actions on items.
fastPickUp: A summary on ways t' loot items on th' ground.
A quick way t' get items on th' ground.

If thar be an item on a tile that ye would like t' loot, ye can either walk onto th' tile (if th' {(DIALOG/3):"Auto Loot" setting} be enabled) or use th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):"Loot Item" action} while facin' th' tile.

Thar can be multiple items on a tile. When ye be standin' over them, ye can press {BINDINGS:GameIdle} t' pass th' turn and gather th' items one at a time. Alternatively, ye can loot all th' items on th' tile by facin' th' tile, then usin' th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):"Loot All Items" action}.

Both o' these actions can be assigned t' an {(HELP/ACTION_SLOTS):action slot} fer faster use.
actions: A guide on how t' interact with items, tiles, or th' things on a tile.

Openin' up th' actions menu {BINDINGS:GameActions} will brin' up a list o' actions ye can perform, usually on th' tile or object yer facin'. Some examples include collectin' fruits from plants, pickin' up {(HELP/DOODADS):doodads} you've placed, and {(HELP/RESTING_SLEEPING):resting}. Thar be also th' "Jump" action that can help ye get out o' tight spots, but be careful when usin' it as it reduces stamina based on th' weight yer carryin'.

All items also have actions that can be performed on them. Th' item's action menu be opened by pressin' {BINDINGS:GameItemMenu}. Tools will usually have actions that can be used on th' facin' tile, while other items will have actions that affect th' tile yer standin' on, or just ye, such as consumin' a food with th' "Eat" action.

Many items have action tiers associated with them. Action tiers affect many different interactions while usin' th' item; things like success chances, stamina depletion rates, etc. Item quality provides a bonus t' action tiers as well. While hoverin' over items, ye can use th' {BINDINGS:GameInspectItem} bind t' show more information on each action th' item can perform and what th' action tier affects.

Since findin' an item in yer duffle and usin' th' item's action menu on it can be a pain, ye can use {(HELP/ACTION_SLOTS):action slots} t' speed up th' process.
stats: Learn how t' understand and manage yer health, stamina, hunger, and thirst.
A numerical representation o' yer wellbein'.

Ye have four core stats: {#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:Health}, {#--STAT-COLOR-STAMINA:Stamina}, {#--STAT-COLOR-HUNGER:Hunger}, and {#--STAT-COLOR-THIRST:Thirst}.

{# Decayin' Stats}

If yer {#--STAT-COLOR-STAMINA:stamina} be 0 and ye take an action, ye will lose {#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:health}.

When yer {#--STAT-COLOR-HUNGER:hunger} or {#--STAT-COLOR-THIRST:thirst} tick below zero, each subsequent time they go down, yer health will be reduced by their current amount. Fer example, if ye have -4 {#--STAT-COLOR-HUNGER:hunger}, and it goes down t' -5, ye will lose 5 {#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:health}.

When yer {#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:health} reaches 0, ye will die.

{# Replenishin' Stats}

{#--STAT-COLOR-STAMINA:Stamina} replenishes slowly over time, but can also be replenished by {(HELP/RESTING_SLEEPING):resting}, most food items, and sleepin' fer maximum benefits.

{#--STAT-COLOR-HUNGER:Hunger} and {#--STAT-COLOR-THIRST:thirst} can be replenished by food and water.

{#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:Health} recovers slowly over time, but can be restored with bandages, other health items, and some types o' food.

{# Maximum Stats}

Usin' skills have th' chance t' increase th' maximum values o' yer stats. An increase in strength will increase th' maximum value o' yer {#--STAT-COLOR-HEALTH:health} as well as yer {(HELP/OVERWEIGHT):weight limit}. An increase in dexterity will increase yer maximum {#--STAT-COLOR-STAMINA:stamina}. An increase in metabolism will increase both {#--STAT-COLOR-HUNGER:hunger} and {#--STAT-COLOR-THIRST:thirst}.

Thar be also {(HELP/ITEM_QUALITIES):epic} items that can be {(HELP/CRAFTIn'):crafted} or found that will increase yer stats when equipped.
doodads: Learn about, and how t' interact with, objects placed in th' world, such as plants or structures.
A guide on plants, structures, and other objects affixed t' th' ground.

Objects attached t' th' ground like plants, piles o' rocks, furnaces, and even campfires be considered t' be a "doodad".

T' "collect" them (pick them up), one or more o' th' followin' options will be available dependin' on th' type o' doodad:

1. Use an item with a "Dig" action, such as a stone shovel.
2. Use th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):"Loot" action}.
3. Use th' "Gather With Hands" action from th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):actions menu}.

Usin' yer bare hands (option #3) can sometimes harm ye (dependin' on th' doodad type).
resourceGathering: A guide on collectin' items from th' environment or creatures.

T' gather resources from trees or rocks, ye must use th' "Chop" or "Mine" action from an item's menu. It be also recommended ye action slot it fer quick usage. See {(HELP/ACTION_SLOTS):Action Slots} fer more information on this functionality. This be recommended as it be harmful t' try t' resource gather without tools. Ye may not always succeed in gatherin' materials (the chances be based on yer skill and tool). Th' {(HELP/ITEM_QUALITIES):quality} o' th' items ye gather be based on yer skill, but mostly based on th' quality o' th' plant or object ye be gatherin' or harvestin'.

Alternatively, instead o' usin' an item in an action slot, ye can instead action slot th' individual "Chop" or "Mine" actions by usin' {BINDINGS:MenuContextMenu} while hoverin' over an action slot. This will automatically use th' best tool fer th' job when assigned and used.

Some resources ain't gathered in this fashion. Things like small plants and other objects attached t' th' ground (referred t' as doodads) require different methods. Review th' {(HELP/DOODADS):"Doodads" help entry} fer more information on these items.

{# Resource Stages}

Many plant-based resources have cycles o' growth, followin' a predictable pattern from "@wayward/game/germinatin'" all th' way up t' "ripenin'". Every plant and fungus features unique resources at each stage o' growth. If ye attempt t' chop or harvest a plant too early, ye may not get th' full amount o' resources. Knowin' th' steps o' growth be also important when {(HELP/GARDENIn'):gardening}.

{# Gatherin' & Harvesting}

Choppin' be a destructive process, meanin', ye will attempt t' gather everythin' from th' plant. Some vegetables and fruits require this t' get th' edible portion, such as potatoes or carrots fer example.

Harvestin' a plant will only attempt t' get what will keep th' plant alive and/or sustainable. This be not always an option fer all plants, and sometimes will only result in gettin' their seeds.
attackingDamage: How t' attack, damage others, and mitigate damage t' ye.
Learn about how t' attack and th' effectiveness o' damage against yerself and others.
creatureTerritories: Understandin' how creature spawnin' works in Wayward.
Learn all about creature territories and how creatures spawn.

In Wayward, th' islands be broken up into different territories. These territories have different sets o' creatures that can spawn in them. These sets change from territory t' territory but be static and usually shift based on th' time o' day. Fer example, one area o' th' island can spawn rats and rabbits durin' th' day, but in th' night, spawn giant spiders and giant rats.

Creatures that be part o' a territory will generally like t' stay in their area and will not chase ye very far, especially if ye keep a good distance from them.

As ye move further out from yer startin' point on yer startin' island, these creatures will get more difficult and change in variety. This also applies t' th' caves below.

As ye travel t' different islands, th' territories will invert in shape and will increase in difficulty as ye get t' th' center o' th' island instead. As ye travel further away from yer startin' island, th' islands will begin t' get harder and harder with more difficult creatures, especially o' th' bilge-suckin' variety becomin' more common.
milestones: A short guide on Wayward's unlockable achievement system.
Th' unlockable achievement system o' th' game.

Milestones be a list o' goals or achievements ye can work towards. Milestone progress be retained between characters and saves. Completin' a milestone will unlock th' correspondin' "Milestone Modifier" fer it. These modifiers can be used when startin' a new game t' add unique gameplay scenarios when enabled. Many o' th' modifiers have positives and negatives associated with them based on gameplay balance and th' milestone's rarity.

Not all {(HELP/GAME_MODES):game modes} have all milestones enabled fer progression.

Most milestones add up over time, such as "Friendly", which counts how many creatures ye tame, or "Chef", which counts how many times ye cook food. However, thar be other milestones that be based on an event like "Navigator" which be unlocked when ye travel away from yer startin' island.
heldItems: Usin' th' main and off hand equipment slots.
Understandin' th' use o' both o' yer hands.

Yer main and off hand equipment slots have different functionalities; however, ye can equip two weapons, two tools, two shields or some godforsaken combination in between. By default, ye will only attack with yer main hand's weapon. Swappin' items in yer hands will not cause a turn t' pass while all other equipment slots will.

T' attack with both weapons in each hand, they be required t' be dual-wieldable (part o' th' {*{!ITEM_GROUP -9885}*} group). T' receive a parryin' defense bonus, ye must be holdin' an item in each hand (one t' parry with, one t' fight with).

Review th' {(HELP/ATTACKIn'_DAMAGE):"Attackin' & Damage" help entry} fer more information on attackin'.
crafting: A guide t' th' craftin' system: What items t' use, and affectin' th' output durability and quality.
Th' ins and outs o' smashin' materials together.

Ye can open th' craftin' dialog with th' "Craftin'" menu bar button, or with {BINDINGS:DialogCrafting}.

Craftin' be simple t' perform, but th' system has a lot o' depth.

{_Success Chance_}

Th' chance o' a successful craft be dependent on yer skill levels and th' difficulty o' th' craft. Th' higher yer skill, th' better yer chance o' success and chance at creatin' a quality item.

After reachin' 30% in a craftin' skill, its craftin' success chance will be revealed in th' item tooltip when craftin'.

{_Which Items Be Used_}

When hoverin' over a recipe (item) in th' craftin' dialog, th' items that will be used t' craft it will be highlighted with a white border.

Ye may notice that th' recipe always uses th' first instance o' th' item in yer duffle. T' change what items be used in a craft, ye can simply change th' order o' th' items in yer duffle.

{_Durability and Quality_}

Th' durability and {(HELP/ITEM_QUALITIES):quality} o' craftin' ingredients affects th' durability and quality o' th' resultin' item:
- Ingredients that be damaged will cause th' resultin' item t' be less durable.
- Usin' superior, remarkable, exceptional, mastercrafted, or relic items and required {(HELP/DOODADS):doodads} increases yer chances t' craft a high-quality item. This counts fer both consumed and required items, but more so fer consumed ones.
- Th' skill used in th' craft will also factor into th' quality o' th' resultin' item. Th' higher yer skills, th' better chance at a higher quality items.
- Decayable items (such as food) also gain decay bonuses from usin' higher quality items in th' craft.

After reachin' 60% in a craftin' skill, yer chance at creatin' a quality item will be revealed in th' item tooltip when craftin'. At 100% skill, yer chance at mastercraftin' an item will be revealed.

{_Tiers_}

Usin' higher tiered items and doodads can produce higher quality crafted items. Fer example, usin' an iron hammer versus a stone hammer or an iron anvil versus a stone anvil. Ye be able t' see which tier an item or doodad be based on its groupin' within th' tooltip o' each item or doodad.

{_Efficacy_}

After reachin' 30% in each craftin' skill, ye will unlock th' ability t' gauge how effectively ye be at craftin' items. This will be displayed in th' messages after craftin' th' item. It will show ye how close t' th' maximum bonus ye be based on th' item/doodad qualities and item/doodad tiers ye be usin' in each craft. Th' higher this bonus is, th' higher th' odds o' craftin' a quality item. After reachin' 90% in th' craftin' skill, an exact efficacy percentage will be revealed.

After 60% in th' craftin' skill be achieved, th' efficacy ratin' will also be revealed in th' item tooltip when craftin'.

{_Unlockin' New Recipes_}

Ye can come across new craftin' recipes by gatherin' th' required items in yer duffle and by findin' old instructional scrolls.
itemQualities: Understandin' th' differences between normal items and those o' quality.
Superior, remarkable, exceptional, mastercrafted, and relic item qualities.

Thar be five item qualities, each with differin' properties and attributes.

1. Superior: Outlined in a {#--COLOR-QUALITY-SUPERIOR:green} border, these items will have slightly higher durability than normal items.
2. Remarkable: Outlined in a {#--COLOR-QUALITY-REMARKABLE:blue} border, these items will have higher durability than normal items.
3. Exceptional: Outlined in a {#--COLOR-QUALITY-EXCEPTIONAL:purple} border, these items will have much higher durability than normal items.
4. Mastercrafted: Outlined in a {#--COLOR-QUALITY-MASTERCRAFTED:tangerine} border, these items will have double th' durability o' exceptional items and will have guaranteed magical properties. This quality can only be crafted.
5. Relic: Outlined in a {#--COLOR-QUALITY-RELIC:rose} border, these items will have very little durability and have many magical properties. This quality can only be found as loot.

Any item can have magical properties, but higher qualities will produce them more frequently. These magical properties include such things as increased skills or stats on equippin', reduced item weight, increased weight capacity, and many more dependin' on th' item.

Besides th' bonuses t' durability, item quality will also provide bonuses t' item uses such as consumption potency, fuel values, and others dependin' on th' type o' item it be. Certain tools and items will also provide bonuses fer specific actions. Fer example, when choppin' or minin', th' higher quality and tier yer tool is, th' higher chance o' success, skill gain, items gained, quality o' items gained, while decreasin' stamina use, and chance o' damagin' plants. Ye can learn more about th' effect o' each item fer each action by inspectin' th' item by pressin' {BINDINGS:GameInspectItem} while hoverin' over an item. Additionally, th' more items o' quality used in a {(HELP/CRAFTIn'):craft}, th' higher th' chance o' producin' a higher quality item be.
death: It will happen t' us all eventually. This contains information about what carries over between lives.

Death be permanent. Although ye may ye be shark bait, all o' th' craftin' recipes ye have discovered will be ready on yer next playthrough. Yer {(HELP/MILESTONES):milestones} will also carry over, providin' ye multiple startin' benefits.

If ye be findin' th' game too difficult, ye can learn more about {(HELP/CreatureTerritories):creature territories} which dictate which creatures spawn where. If ye wish t' permanently modify th' game's difficulty, it be recommended that ye play a {(HELP/GAME_MODES):"custom mode" game} with options set t' yer likin'.
taming: A small guide on how t' tame creatures usin' a variety o' methods.
Learn about all th' options fer tamin' creatures.

There's a variety o' methods fer attemptin' t' tame creatures in Wayward. These include:

1. Usin' th' {(HELP/ACTIONS): "Tame" action in th' actions menu} when facin' a creature. Th' chances o' success o' this method be quite low, especially at lower skill levels and varies dependin' on what th' creature be and their difficulty.
2. Usin' th' "Offer" option on an item when facin' a creature. If th' creature wants th' item, it will accept ye as its owner.
3. Droppin' items on th' ground and havin' creatures move over it will have them become tame towards ye (or some godforsaken player that be closest t' th' creature) if they accept th' item.

Bilge-suckin' creatures be harder t' tame and will sometimes reject ye as its owner even when offerin' items. This chance be based on yer {$SKILL:27} skill.

Usin' th' offer item action may be hard, especially in a multiplayer settin' whar creatures can move aroun' as turns tick by. Ye can use {(HELP/ACTION_SLOTS):action slots} t' more smartly offer items t' creatures, usin' a single bind.
restingSleeping: Tips on how t' get th' best regenerative effects while restin' and sleepin'.
Learnin' th' differences between restin' and sleepin' and additional bonuses that can be applied.
overweight: Learn th' impacts o' bein' overweight.

If ye be carryin' too much weight, ye will be "Encumbered". Th' first level o' encumbrance will slow down yer movement and reduce {(HELP/STATS):stamina regeneration}. If it progresses t' th' second level, "Overburdened", ye will take damage as ye move.

Ye can drop items from yer duffle with {BINDINGS:GameItemDrop}, {BINDINGS:GameItemDropAll} (to drop all o' one type o' item), ye can use th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):"Drop" action on th' item}, or ye can drag and drop them on t' th' game screen.
merchants: Learn how t' trade and interact with wanderin' merchants.

Ye can drag items into th' wanderin' merchant's duffle t' receive barter credit. Alternatively, ye can also use th' item's menu t' trade as well. Ye can use this barter credit t' trade fer other items that ye wish t' receive in return. Ye can come back at some godforsaken time t' trade with th' merchant, but be careful, they may "wander" away fer good eventually.

Yer {$SKILL:29} skill influences th' amount o' barter credit received when tradin' items; however, merchants will always trade items back at a higher value.

If ye do not wish t' trade with th' merchant, ye can also choose t' instigate an attack towards th' wanderer usin' th' {(HELP/ACTIONS):"Attack" option in th' actions menu}. But, be careful; they won't take kindly t' such hostile actions.
gardening: Learn about th' cycles o' growth fer plant-life and tips on gardenin'.
Tips on gardenin' and information on growth cycles.

Th' full plant life cycle be represented within Wayward. In order, these be: germinatin', seedlin', vegetative, buddin', flowerin', ripenin', and dead. Fungus follows th' same steps, but be named: germinatin', spreadin', formin', youn', fruitin', and full. Each o' these stages provide different {(HELP/RESOURCE_GATHERIn'):resources when choppin', gatherin', or harvesting}.

Th' {(HELP/ITEM_QUALITIES):quality} o' terrain will increase th' speed at which plants and mushrooms will grow.

Fertile soil promotes th' spread and propagation properties o' all plants and mushrooms. By combinin' compost (made with two compostable items), bone meal (through th' grindin' o' bones), and ash, ye can craft fertilizer. Combine it with soil (produced when diggin' dirt) t' create fertile soil. Fertile soil can be placed down, tilled, then used as th' target fer plantin' seeds and mushrooms. Usin' fertile soil will increase th' speed at which plants and mushrooms grow on top o' th' bonus provided by its quality.

Additionally, ye can attempt t' water plants (by usin' th' "Pour" action on water containers) which will give a one-time growth bonus. Waterin' plants will also heal them if they become damaged through harvestin', tramplin', or other means.
itemProtection: Protect items t' belay them from bein' consumed or destroyed.
Learn about th' effects o' item protection.

Protectin' an item has th' followin' effects:

1. It cannot be consumed in craftin'.
2. It cannot be used fer some godforsaken action that consumes or destroys th' item includin': dismantle, disassemble, stoke fire, eat, etc.
3. When at 0 durability, it cannot be used as a recipe requirement in craftin'.
4. When reachin' 0 durability, if th' item be equipped, it will automatically be unequipped.
5. It cannot be dropped or thrown on tiles that would lose th' item like in deep sea water or th' void.
6. It won't be used as th' "best item" in action slots.

Additionally, when th' {(DIALOG/3):"Disable Craftin' with Protected Required Items" gameplay setting} be enabled, protected required items will not be used in craftin' at all. Consumed protected items will ne'er be used in crafts regardless o' what this settin' be set to.

T' smartly toggle protection on an item, use {BINDINGS:GameItemProtectToggle}.
gameModes: Explorin' th' different ways t' play Wayward and modifyin' th' difficulty.
Explanation o' th' different game and turn modes and difficulty in Wayward.
multiplayer: Information on th' multiplayer system in Wayward.

Multiplayer in Wayward be enabled fer up t' 32 players. Multiplayer works on a simulated real-time mode whar each turn happens on a fixed interval. "Casual" and "Hardcore" modes work a bit differently than in single player. Casual mode allows players t' respawn as per normal, but in hardcore mode, when ye die ye will continue t' play in dredgie form, allowin' ye t' spectate but not interact normally. Multiplayer also allows fer a special PVP flag t' be set t' allow players t' hurt and kill other players. Multiplayer options can be set in th' multiplayer menu via th' pause menu accessed with {BINDINGS:GamePause}.

Creature spawn rates and creature difficulty be based on how many connected players thar be and will scale and average based on each individual player in some circumstances.

{# Commands}
Ye can use several special commands while playin' multiplayer. T' see a list o' all possible commands, type "/commands" in th' chat bar and hit enter. Th' followin' commands be also available fer use:

{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/players}  Shows a list o' all connected players.
{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/ping}  Shows yer latency t' th' host player.
{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/kick}  Allows th' host t' kick a player.
{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/banned}  Shows a list o' all banned players.
{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/ban}  Allows th' host t' ban a player.
{#--TEXT-SECONDARY:/unban}  Allows th' host t' unban a player.
bugs: Did ye get an error? Please report it!
Learn how t' report bugs and debug Wayward.

Please report all th' issues ye spot! While we try t' ensure Wayward be very stable, some things fall through th' cracks. Wayward be still in beta status and our development team be very small. Therefore, without players reportin' issues, they may stay unresolved. If ye do report yer bugs, we cannot express just how much we appreciate them!

With that bein' said, {(https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=798938225):here be a guide on how t' report and debug issues ye have with Wayward}.

Report bugs and issues at:
1. {(https://steamcommunity.com/app/379210/discussions/1/):Steam Discussions Bug Reports forum} OR
2. {(https://discord.gg/wayward):Discord}

hideGlue: Glue created by boilin' hides t' break down collagen t' form a powerful adhesive.
animalSkull: A large hollowed-out, bleached animal skull, suitable fer craftin' into a provisional helmet.
graniteArrow: A projectile t' be fired from a bow, crafted with an arrowhead and feather t' control flight.
graniteArrowhead: Crafted from granite and t' be used in th' craftin' o' arrows. Could also be used as a carvin' implement.
pileOfAsh: Th' powdery remains o' burned matter.
barkLeggings: Rudimentary leg armor, crafted from stron' tree bark and secured with strin'.
barkShield: A makeshift shield, used t' block incomin' attacks, made with tree bark and wrapped with strin'.
barkTunic: Tree bark chest armor bound together with strin'.
bone: A heavy, sun-bleached animal bone, suitable fer rudimentary combat, gatherin', or craftin' into more useful items.
branch: A typical tree branch, useful fer a variety o' crafts or stokin' a fire.
cactusSpines: Thin, lon' spikes, suitable fer craftin' into makeshift needles.
graniteFlooring: Primitive floorin' created by granite in an organized pattern, fillin' some godforsaken gaps.
cookedMeat: Adequately heated meat, safe and ready fer consumption.
earthworm: A live wrigglin' worm, effective fer bait or eatin' on its own.
feather: Some bright white plumage from an avian creature.
fertilizer: A rich mixture o' organic chemical compounds, suitable fer combinin' with soil t' create fertile soil.
waterskinOfSeawater: A waterskin full o' seawater, not suitable fer drinkin' without desalination.
firePlough: A fire makin' device which uses a stick and groove method t' create heat through friction.
beggartickSeeds: Dried beggartick seeds which can be planted t' grow flowers.
fossil: A carbonized fossil o' a species lon' since extinct.
goldCoins: Shiny, coins casted from pure gold, from a lost civilization unknown t' ye.
goldenChalice: A large, ornate, and resplendent chalice.
goldenRing: A golden rin', most likely used as a sign o' wealth and power.
goldShortSword: An ornate, but soft sword, forged from solid gold. Not suitable fer combat due t' its softness.
grassSeeds: Small dried grass seeds. Can be planted t' grow grass.
ironOre: Unprocessed, raw iron ore. Can be smelted or worked with in wrought iron form.
woodenDowels: A gatherin' o' small wooden pegs. Used as hinges in woodworkin' or as kindlin' in firemakin'.
granite: A rather large piece o' granite, handy fer craftin' many tools and devices.
leafBedroll: A provisional bed with poor insulation and scratchy half-dried leaves, used fer sleepin' or restin'.
hide: A fresh thick hide, cut from an animal and de-furred.
leaves: A handful o' foliage used as compost, t' stoke a fire, or as tinder when dried.
limestone: A mineral-rich rock that can be ground into a powder. Useful fer metal and glass production.
log: A sturdy piece o' wood, useful fer construction or as a fuel fer a fire.
graniteMortarAndPestle: Used fer grindin' and crushin', made from smooth stones.
buttonMushrooms: Lon' lastin' common white mushrooms. They appear safe t' consume.
nopal: A de-spined cactus pad, filled with refreshin' liquid and nourishment.
peat: A dried mass o' sponge-like plants, great fer fire fuel and compostin'.
sandstone: A soft, malleable rock, useful fer construction and tool makin'.
pileOfGravel: A large pile o' damp stone and sand.
pileOfBeachSand: A large pile o' fine beach sand, useful fer makin' glass when refined.
woodenArrow: A provisional wooden projectile t' be fired from a bow. Crafted with a feather t' control flight.
graniteAxe: A simple stone axe used fer choppin' wood or as a carvin' implement.
bandage: A tattered piece o' fabric, used t' staunch wounds and prevent infection.
wovenFabric: A makeshift piece o' fibrous tissue, woven together into fabric.
cactusNeedle: A needle from a cactus plant, useful in craftin' smaller, more intricate items.
graniteShovel: A diggin' tool made o' granite, used t' collect different materials from th' ground or t' route water.
woodenSpear: A makeshift, easy t' craft huntin' weapon. Makes fer an ideal ranged weapon.
suture: A sharp needle tool with an attached thin strin', used t' sew and close gapin' wounds.
raft: A small, simple boat; a smarter alternative t' swimmin'. Effective fer traversin' large expanses o' water.
rawMeat: A raw, bloody chunk o' meat. Cookin' be recommended before consumption.
raspberries: Lush, ripe raspberries, plucked from a raspberry bush.
flyAmanita: An odd lookin', and even odder smellin' red spotted mushroom.
rope: A thick, twisted batch o' strings, useful fer heavy-duty bindin'.
mapleSeeds: Small, winged seeds that seemingly dance and twirl in th' air as they fall from a maple tree.
badderlocks: A stringy wet mass o' seaweed. Can be used as cordage or eatin' in desperation.
sharpGlass: A semi-opaque shard o' glass, formed after meltin' sand down.
sharpGranite: A sharpened piece o' granite, useful fer craftin', tool makin', and carvin' when required.
skullcap: A hollowed-out animal skull, useful as a provisional helmet.
smoothGranite: A round, smoothed granite stone, useful fer many crafts.
soil: A pile o' moist dirt. Th' heavy smell o' earth permeates yer nostrils when holdin' it.
graniteSpear: A huntin' weapon crafted with a granite stone head, suitable as a throwin' weapon.
stones: A mass o' small rocks o' all different shapes, sizes, and colors. Can be used fer throwin' or craftin'.
graniteWall: A series o' interlaced stones and rocks, shaped into a vertical wall structure. Can be built t' keep enemies out.
string: Woven fabric; th' cornerstone o' all craftin' materials, mainly used fer bindin'.
strippedBark: A stron', fibrous shavin' from a branch, useful as cordage.
leather: A durable, tannin-treated piece o' leather. Used in craftin' armor and other tools.
tannin: A natural treatin' agent. T' be applied on hides t' create tanned leather.
milkThistleSeeds: Small hard seeds, used fer growin' milk thistle plants.
treeBark: A tough, dense chunk o' bark, broken off from a tree. Can be used fer kindlin' or strippin' into cordage.
honeyFungus: A parasitic fungi, grown from a tree and possibly edible.
clematisVine: A lon', windin' clematis vine, suitable as cordage.
twigs: A small pile o' sticks and tree limbs. Mostly used fer kindlin'.
waterskin: A portable water container, made from stitched leather.
woodenPole: A lon' piece o' wood, carved and shaved down into a smooth rod from a branch or log.
peatBandage: A fabric bandage combined with peat as an effective antiseptic.
bow: A bent wooden pole with a shorter strin' tied t' both ends. Th' tension o' th' strin' be used t' fire arrows.
bowDrill: An advanced fire startin' device. Uses th' strin' on a bow t' rotate into th' wood, reducin' much effort.
fishingNet: A checkered weave o' strin' with weights on each corner, used t' trap and catch fish.
rawCod: Slimy t' th' touch, but healthy and delicious t' eat. Can be cooked fer a better meal.
cookedCod: A seared, well-cooked cod, ready t' consume and enjoy.
graniteCampfire: A groupin' o' rocks shaped into a rin' t' contain a fire.
vineWhip: A makeshift weapon made simply with vines wrapped together.
pileOfSnow: A meltin' snow pile. Useful t' drink in desperate need, but be smart about it!
barkTorch: A torch wrapped and bound by stripped tree bark, providin' natural oils t' increase th' life o' th' torch.
litBarkTorch: Provides light t' yer surroundings when equipped and can also be used t' start other fires.
handDrill: A rudimentary fire makin' tool which uses a stick and another piece o' wood. Both hands be used t' twist th' stick against wood, makin' friction t' create an ember fer th' fire.
smallBag: A leather pouch used fer holdin' a few items, carried at yer waist, reducin' encumbrance.
shale: A brittle but sharp carvin' implement.
sharpenedBone: A sharp bone, useful fer carvin' other objects.
grindstone: A coarse rock useful fer sandin', sharpenin', and repairin' other items.
rawFishSteak: A raw piece o' fish, cut into a fillet. Good t' eat as is, but be tastier cooked.
cookedFishSteak: A cooked fish fillet, seared on th' outside and delicious.
waterskinOfDesalinatedWater: A waterskin full o' freshly desalinated seawater.
boatPaddle: A makeshift boat paddle used with boats and rafts, or combat if in dire need.
bullBoat: A boat made with leather and framed with curved wooden poles. Used t' traverse water and travel t' new locations.
refinedSand: A finely ground sand, useful in makin' glass.
spyglass: An improvised, short-range telescope, which can be used t' see slightly further away in some godforsaken direction when equipped.
retort: A glass container which can be heated fer desalination, a process used t' make seawater drinkable.
rawClay: A soft, formable mud. Suitable fer buildin' materials, tool-makin', and more.
rawClayBlowpipe: An unfired clay blowpipe used in glassblowin'. Unusable until it has been fired.
clayBlowpipe: A sturdy blowpipe used fer glassblowin'.
leatherBelt: Made from tanned animal hide, cut, wrapped, and stitched together t' tie aroun' th' waist.
leatherTunic: A leather garment which provides protection fer th' torso.
leatherBoots: Malleable yet tough foot protection, crafted from tanned animal hide.
leatherCap: A hat made o' leather, double layered fer extra sturdiness.
leatherGorget: A circlet o' leather, bound in two, stitched together and used as neck protection.
leatherPants: Basic leather leggings with just enough paddin' t' provide some leg protection.
leatherGloves: Leather-bound hand protection, crafted from tanned animal hide.
graniteFurnace: An enclosed structure made o' granite, which traps in th' heat t' keep a lon'-lastin', high-temperature fire.
sandstoneKiln: Similar t' a furnace, but constructed with holystone and in a way that allows fer proper heat distribution fer craftin' glass and clay items.
ironTongs: Durable iron tongs used t' grab hot items, protectin' yer hands from damage.
talc: A very chalky mineral, only useful in its powder form.
talcumPowder: Chalky and abundantly absorbent t' th' touch. An agent required fer castin' o' advanced metals.
woodenSandCastFlask: A mold fer castin' metal into some godforsaken shape, made with green sand and placed into a carved-out log.
lens: Glass formed into a partially convex shape. It allows focusin' sunlight into a single location, creatin' enough heat fer a fire.
plantRoots: A tangled mess o' roots, with earth still hangin' from th' tips.
lockpick: An improvised needle and pron' that should be stron' enough t' pick a lock or two.
boneNeedle: A thin, hard, sharp needle, carved from bone.
pineapple: A juicy, ripe pineapple, loaded with vitamins and thirst-quenchin' attributes.
tatteredMap: An old torn map covered with drawings and scribbles, a bit hard t' make sense o' on first glance.
coal: A black and brittle mineral, stainin' anythin' it touches, but useful as fuel.
smeltedWroughtIron: A heavily oxidized and unpurified form o' iron, used in th' forgin' o' brittle tools, weapons, and armor.
limestonePowder: A white, mineral-dense powder used in glass temperin' and th' purifyin' o' metals.
smeltedIron: A solid nugget o' iron, ready t' be formed or melted and cast in many ways.
backpack: Crafted with leather, it's suitable fer holdin' many items on yer back, reducin' overall weight.
rottenMeat: Acrid decomposin' animal tissue. Ye would not want t' eat this, but can be used in compost.
graniteHammer: A rudimentary stone hammer, braced on th' end o' a pole with strin'. Used fer gatherin' and repairin'.
rawChicken: A small, plump and de-feathered cackle carcass, ready fer cookin'.
cookedChicken: A well-cooked cackle, ready t' consume and sure t' satisfy.
graniteAnvil: A solid granite anvil. Used in th' production o' metal armor, weapons, and tools.
woodenChest: A large wooden container that can fit many items while placed on th' ground. Foods will decay slower within it.
ironShortSword: A stron', sharp blade designed fer thrustin' and slashin'.
ironBreastplate: Durable, armor worn over th' torso. One could take a serious beatin' while wearin' this.
ironBoots: Heavy iron plated boots, shieldin' yer feet from damage.
ironHelmet: Iron plated headgear designed t' withstand heavy blows.
ironGorget: A round metal brace worn aroun' th' neck and over th' shoulders.
ironCuisses: Iron leggings; t' be strapped on t' th' thighs and function as leg protection.
ironGauntlets: Iron gloves designed t' be protective and durable, while maintainin' as much flexibility as possible.
ironHeater: A large and heavy iron shield, used fer blockin' projectiles or melee attacks.
sandstoneWall: A constructed wall built from mined holystone.
sandstoneFlooring: A group o' holystone bricks, placed in a grid t' be used as floorin'.
spiderSilk: A delicate but stron' strand o' silk, produced by a spider. Can be used as cordage.
animalFat: A gelatinous shavin' o' animal fat, slimy t' th' touch. Useful as a rendered fuel.
tallowTorch: A torch; wrapped in rendered animal fat, producin' a lon'-lastin' light source.
clayFlakes: Dried shavings o' clay. Created by shavin' clay and dryin' over a period o' time.
greenSand: A form o' malleable sand made with clay, used t' make molds fer metal castin'.
oldInstructionalScroll: A tattered sheet o' paper with some roughly scribbled instructions and diagrams.
slimeGelatin: A lump o' slime gelatin which jiggles upon yer touch. Can be used t' preserve food, or melted down and used as glue.
slimeGlue: A glue consistin' o' boiled slime gelatin that can be used t' bind and reinforce items.
cookedSpiderMeat: Crispy spider meat. Not th' best texture or flavor, but contains th' more edible portions o' th' deceased arachnid.
spiderMeat: A spider's fleshy innards. It's hard t' stomach, even when cooked. Try not t' think about what yer eatin'.
ironLockpick: A pair o' iron picks and wrenches, durable enough t' pick th' most adept o' locks.
rottingVegetation: A stinkin' mash o' organic plant matter, now usable as compost. Unless ye want t' risk eatin' it.
chives: A stron' smellin' and tastin' plant, packed with nutrients and vitamins.
ironHammer: A stron' hammer with an iron head, perfect fer shapin' and repairin' items.
ironSpear: A polearm with a stron' pointed tip forged from iron.
ironShovel: A heavy iron diggin' implement, liftin' and breakin' through even th' toughest gravels and soils.
ironDoubleAxe: An axe with a forged, double sided head, ideal fer both combat and choppin' trees.
ironPickaxe: A robust minin' implement, with a blade forged from iron.
inkstick: A hardened brick o' ink, used fer drawin' and paintin'.
coconut: A fibrous and heavy fruit. Difficult t' consume, but packed with plenty o' caloric-dense coconut meat and milk.
palmLeaf: A large leaf from a palm tree. Th' stron' inner fibers o' th' leaf be perfect as cordage.
offal: A mound o' organs, tissue, and other undesirable portions o' an unlucky animal.
boneFragments: A bundle o' bones from a small vertebrate. Some cracked, others shattered. Th' pieces be quite sharp.
litPoleTorch: A wooden pole that has been lit on fire. Not suitable fer lon' journeys in th' darkness.
cottonBoll: A boll o' cotton, a protective casin' that contains th' seeds and fluffy cotton, ready t' be separated.
cottonSeeds: De-fluffed and cleaned cotton seeds, ready t' plant.
cottonFabric: A soft piece o' cloth spun from cotton.
bonePole: A smooth cudgel crafted from a large bone.
tourniquet: A hard stud twisted together with a strin'. Used t' twist aroun' a bleedin' wound t' stem th' flow o' blood.
wroughtIronPickaxe: A dual-headed minin' implement. One head be heavy and blunt, th' other, spiked t' cut through rock with ease.
wroughtIronDoubleAxe: A dual-bladed axe which can provide enough slashin' damage fer both combat and gatherin'.
wroughtIronShovel: A shovel with an angled, pointed head, useful fer diggin' and water routin'.
wroughtIronSpear: A polearm with pointed head, crafted from wrought iron. Used in melee or thrown in combat.
wroughtIronHammer: A large mallet crafted from wrought iron. Useful fer repairin' and sometimes minin'.
wroughtIronLockpick: A set o' picks and wrenches made from wrought iron, used fer pickin' and unlockin' locked devices.
wroughtIronShield: A sturdy wrought iron shield, made by bendin' large sheets o' metal into shape.
wroughtIronGauntlets: Intricate and sturdy, these wrought iron gloves fit snugly on yer hands.
wroughtIronCuisses: Wrought iron leggings, strapped and padded aroun' th' thighs t' reduce most damage.
wroughtIronGorget: A molded piece o' metal, used t' protect th' area aroun' th' neck and shoulders.
wroughtIronHelmet: Usin' a barbute design, this iron helmet shields th' head from most kinds o' attacks.
wroughtIronBoots: Wrought iron footwear. Heavy and made specifically fer protectin' feet and lower legs.
wroughtIronBreastplate: A large wrought iron chest plate, worn over th' torso.
wroughtIronShortSword: A short, sharpened blade fitted into a solid hilt and forged from wrought iron. A good, stron' weapon.
woodenWall: A sturdy set o' bound logs, formin' a protective wall that can be placed.
woodenFlooring: Wooden floor boards; planed t' equal height and length.
woodenDoor: A door crafted from lon' wooden planks with large wooden hinges. Can be opened and closed when built.
fishingRod: A flexible, smooth wooden rod with a strin' line and sharpened hook. Used fer fly fishin'.
messageInABottle: An old cloudy bottle with an unidentified object contained inside.
pileOfCompost: A mix o' decayin' organic matter, full o' chemical nutrients and great fer growin' plants when combined with other fertilizer components.
fishGlue: A semi-permanent glue produced by boilin' down fish bones t' form this tacky, sticky liquid. Stron' enough t' hold a thin' or two together fer awhile, but would not work fer strengthenin' or reinforcement.
woodenShavings: A dry bunch o' wooden shavings, used t' ignite kindlin' when startin' a fire.
graniteDeadfall: A large, flat granite rock, propped up with a stick. Once set, anythin' that triggers it will be crushed or injured from th' fallin' rock.
snare: A short pole pushed into th' ground with a strin' attached. Designed t' ensnare creatures in its slipknot.
waterskinOfMedicinalWater: A soothin' mixture o' plants and roots. Used t' heal poisons and illnesses.
charcoalBandage: A cloth bandage, coated in charcoal and used fer its natural antiseptic and coagulant properties.
woodenTongs: A pair o' simple wood tongs, used t' loot hot objects without injury.
wroughtIronTongs: A pair o' tongs, forged from wrought iron. Used t' lift hot objects without injury.
sheetOfGlass: A cloudy tempered piece o' glass. Practical fer many optical tools and other simple devices used t' harness th' sun.
solarStill: A still that collects condensation and filters it into a hole beneath th' glass, desalinatin' th' water and drainin' it into a container.
